docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Welcome to my Digital Fabrication and Modeling Documentation Website, a comprehensive record of my learning journey throughout the course. This platform captures my design decisions, technical explorations, and fabrication workflows, reflecting both conceptual understanding and hands-on practice.    The documentation is developed using MkDocs with the Material theme and is fully version-controlled with GitHub, ensuring transparency, traceability of changes, and continuous publication of updated content.  ## Professional Background  My name is NIYOMUGENGA Prosper, and I hold a Bachelor’s degree in Electronics and Telecommunication Engineering. I am currently pursuing a Master’s degree in Internet of Things (IoT), where my academic focus is on embedded systems, connected devices, and intelligent technologies.

docs.title: Course Documentation Overview
docs.text:
This documentation site is structured to guide you through my digital modeling and fabrication learning journey. You can navigate through:

  • Documentation Manual – Guides on setup, workflow, modeling, and fabrication
  • Daily Documentation – Daily progress logs including design decisions, screenshots, and fabrication notes
  • Reflection – Lessons learned, critical analysis, and improvements throughout the course

Each section combines text explanations, images, diagrams, and step-by-step workflows to provide a complete understanding of the design and fabrication process.

docs.title: Day 01 – Building a Documentation Website with MkDocs Material
Documenting Design & Fabrication Processes
docs.text: Digital fabrication links digital design and physical production through computer-controlled tools such as CNC machines, laser cutters, and 3D printers. It evolved from manual craft and industrial manufacturing to enable rapid prototyping, precision, iteration, and hybrid workflows, transforming fabrication into an accessible process for innovation, education, and localized production.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Digital Modeling for Fabrication refers to the process of creating accurate digital 2D or 3D models using computer-aided design (CAD) tools, specifically intended for digital fabrication technologies.

  • The digital model defines the shape, dimensions, and features of an object
  • It accounts for material properties, tolerances, joints, and assembly methods
  • The model is directly used to generate machine instructions for tools such as laser cutters, CNC routers, and 3D printers

docs.title: 1. Printable Product for Experiencing the 3D Machine
Activity 1 – FreeCAD Model
docs.text:
Design Characteristics

  • Two flat faces at 90°
  • Two circular holes for screws or bolts
  • Simple geometry with no complex curves
  • One filleted corner for safety and manufacturability

docs.title: 2. Activity 2 – Inkscape Model
docs.text:
Press-Fit Box Panel (2D Vector)

Task 1: Design Characteristics

  • A flat rectangular panel
  • Rectangular slots cut into the edges
  • Slots sized to match material thickness
  • Designed to slide and lock with other panels
  • Entirely 2D vector geometry

docs.title: 3. Modeling Approach (Inkscape) of Final Product
docs.text:
Inkscape is an open-source vector graphics design software widely used for 2D digital modeling in fabrication workflows, especially for laser cutting, vinyl cutting, and CNC engraving.

In this modeling approach, designs are created as vector paths rather than raster images, ensuring precise, scalable, and machine-readable geometry. Inkscape allows accurate control of dimensions, line thickness, colors, and layers, which are essential for defining cutting, engraving, and scoring operations.

docs.title: 1. Overview
docs.text:
On Day 3, the focus was on PCB design for fabrication, specifically creating a single-sided microcontroller PCB using KiCad. The main goal was to understand the complete workflow, from schematic creation to PCB layout, and finally preparing the design for milling and soldering.

KiCad is a free and open-source PCB design software that supports the entire PCB development cycle, including schematic capture, layout design, and generating fabrication-ready files. It is widely used for both learning and professional PCB development because it ensures precise and manufacturable designs.

docs.title: 2. KiCad Workflow
docs.text:
The PCB design process in KiCad follows a structured workflow, where each step builds on the previous one to ensure a robust and functional final product:

  1. Schematic Creation – Define the electrical connections between components using logical symbols
  2. Footprint Assignment – Link schematic symbols to physical footprints
  3. PCB Layout – Arrange components and route traces
  4. Design Rule Check (DRC) – Validate the design against manufacturing constraints
  5. Fabrication Files Generation – Export Gerber and drill files

docs.title: Objective
docs.text:
Design a single-sided PCB in KiCad with the following specifications:

  • Microcontroller: ATtiny45
  • Functionality: Control an LED using a push button
  • Programming Interface: 6-pin ISP header
  • Fabrication Suitability: Optimized for PCB milling and hand soldering

docs.title: Expected Activity Outcomes
docs.text:
• Translate a schematic into a manufacturable PCB layout
  • Apply design rules to ensure reliability
  • Generate fabrication files ready for milling and assembly

docs.title: Challenges
docs.text: Routing the PCB presented significant challenges, particularly because in single-sided PCB designs, traces cannot cross each other. This limitation required careful planning of component placement and trace routing to avoid congestion.

docs.title: Key Learnings
docs.text:
• Component placement is critical for successful single-sided PCB routing
  • Early planning reduces routing complexity
  • Designing for fabrication requires thinking beyond electrical connections

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Materials are not just components; they are the foundation of what we create. They determine durability, functionality, and sustainability. Every material choice influences the entire product lifecycle, from fabrication to long-term use.

Key principles explored during this day include:

  • Materials define what is possible, durable, and sustainable
  • Fabrication methods influence form, accuracy, and cost
  • Design decisions must align material and process for optimal results

docs.title: 1. Wood
docs.text: Wood is a widely used material in fabrication due to its availability, workability, and natural aesthetics. It is commonly used in furniture, enclosures, and structural prototypes.

docs.title: Common Processes
docs.text:
• CNC Routing for intricate and repeatable shapes
  • Laser Cutting for precise detailing and fast prototyping

Figure 1: Wood material used in fabrication processes.

docs.title: 2. Plastics
docs.text:
Plastics offer a balance between flexibility, strength, and lightweight properties. One example explored is carbon fiber filament, a functional filament created by mixing carbon fiber powder with PETG.

Carbon fiber is an extremely strong and lightweight fiber-reinforced plastic. It is commonly used in applications that require high strength-to-weight ratio, such as mechanical parts and structural components.

Figure 2: Plastic material example used in fabrication.

docs.title: 3. Metals
docs.text: Metals are indispensable for applications that demand exceptional strength and durability. They are widely used across industries such as aerospace, construction, electronics, and consumer goods.

docs.title: Common Metals
docs.text:
• Copper
  • Aluminum
  • Steel
  • Brass

Figure 3: Copper board and metal cutting tools.

docs.title: 4. Shurtape Brand Tape
docs.text:
Shurtape is a well-known manufacturer of industrial and professional-grade tapes. The name “Shurtape” is visible on the inside core of the tape roll.

Shurtape produces a wide range of tapes, including:

  • Double-sided cloth tapes
  • Paper tapes

These tapes are commonly used for mounting, holding, splicing, and securing materials such as carpet and fabrication components.

Figure 4: Shurtape brand industrial tape.

docs.title: 5. Black Spanner Wrench
docs.text:
Spanner wrenches are specialized tools used to tighten, loosen, or adjust round nuts and retaining rings that do not have traditional hexagonal or square edges.

They are commonly used in mechanical assembly, machine maintenance, and precision adjustments.

Figure 5: Black spanner wrench used for mechanical adjustments.

docs.title: Reflection
docs.text: Understanding materials through hands-on making reinforces the idea that design is inseparable from material choice. Selecting the right material and fabrication process leads to better performance, lower cost, and more sustainable outcomes.

docs.title: Introduction to Laser Cutting
docs.text:
Laser cutting is a digital fabrication process that uses a highly focused laser beam to cut, engrave, or etch materials with very high precision. The laser melts, burns, or vaporizes material along a programmed path derived from a digital design file.

Laser cutting is widely used because it offers:

  • High precision and repeatability
  • Clean edges with minimal post-processing
  • Compatibility with many materials such as wood, plastics, and thin metals

docs.title: 1. Hardware Components
docs.text: The laser cutting machine consists of several critical hardware and interface elements that ensure safe and accurate operation.

docs.title: Safety and Control Components
docs.text:
• Red Mushroom-Head Button (Top Left) This is the Emergency Stop (E-STOP) button. When pressed, it immediately cuts power to hazardous machine elements to prevent injury. It is a latching type and must be manually reset by twisting or pulling after the emergency is resolved.

  • Safety Interlock and Key Switch The key switch is part of the safety interlock system. It ensures the machine cannot operate unless required safety conditions are met, such as a protective door being closed. The key also prevents unauthorized operation.

  • Black Knobs or Buttons (Center Top) These are used for specific machine operations, such as:

  • Motor speed control
  • Feed rate adjustment

  • Switching between manual and automatic modes

  • Touch Screen Interface This is the primary human-machine interface used to:

  • Load programs
  • Monitor machine status
  • Control laser operations

docs.title: Screen Interface Elements
docs.text:
The screen interface provides real-time operational control and feedback.

  • Pause and Stop Buttons (On Screen) These buttons allow controlled stopping of the machine during normal operation. Unlike the physical E-STOP, they stop the process gracefully.

  • Time and Parameter Display Indicators such as 00:00:48 and 2.6 typically show:

  • Elapsed job time

  • Software version or machine parameter values

  • Central Graphic and New Project Option The graphic represents the machine’s operational state or laser path visualization. The New Project option allows starting or loading a new job.

  • On-Screen E-STOP A software-based emergency stop that mirrors the function of the physical E-STOP through control logic.

  • Status Indicators Icons and text such as WB 172.17.26.21 and WiFi Connected indicate:

  • Network connectivity
  • Machine IP address on the local network

docs.title: 2. Heart of the Machine
docs.text:
The most critical component of a laser cutter is the laser source, which generates the high-energy beam required for cutting and engraving.

Figure 1: Laser source, the heart of the laser cutting machine.

docs.title: 3. Laser Cutting System
docs.text:
A laser cutting system works by focusing a high-energy laser beam onto the surface of a material to cut, engrave, or mark it.

The general working principle includes:

  • The laser source generates a coherent and intense beam of light
  • The beam is guided using mirrors and focused through a lens
  • When the focused beam hits the material, it melts, burns, or vaporizes it
  • An assist gas such as air, oxygen, or nitrogen removes molten material
  • The motion system moves the laser head or workpiece along the programmed path

docs.title: Main Parts of a Laser Cutter
a) Laser Source
docs.text:
• Generates the laser beam
  • Common types include:
  • CO₂ laser
  • Fiber laser
  • Diode laser
  • Determines cutting power and material compatibility

docs.title: b) Power Supply
docs.text: • Provides electrical energy to excite the laser medium

docs.title: c) Mirrors
docs.text:
• Direct the laser beam from the source to the cutting head
  • Ensure accurate beam alignment

docs.title: d) Focusing Lens
docs.text:
• Concentrates the laser beam into a very small spot
  • Higher focus results in higher energy density and precise cutting

docs.title: e) Cutting Head or Nozzle
docs.text:
• Houses the focusing lens
  • Directs assist gas onto the cutting area

docs.title: f) Assist Gas System
docs.text:
• Uses air, oxygen, or nitrogen
  • Removes molten material and improves cut quality

docs.title: g) Motion Control System
docs.text:
• Includes motors, rails, belts, or lead screws
  • Moves the laser head or work bed in X–Y and sometimes Z directions

docs.title: h) Work Bed
docs.text:
• Supports the material being cut
  • Often honeycomb or slatted to reduce reflections

docs.title: i) Control System
docs.text:
• Includes controller and software
  • Converts CAD designs into machine instructions
  • Controls speed, laser power, and cutting paths

docs.title: Laser Cutting Operations
docs.text: Laser cutters can perform multiple operations depending on power and settings.

docs.title: Cutting
docs.text:
• Laser completely penetrates the material
  • Used for parts, shapes, and profiles

docs.title: Engraving
docs.text:
• Laser removes only the surface layer
  • Used for text, logos, and decorative patterns

docs.title: Marking
docs.text:
• Laser changes surface color without removing material
  • Used for labeling and identification

Figure 2: Complete laser cutting system and working principle.
